majtheme: Human development,Social protection and risk management
trustfund:
TF093854-AFGHANISTAN SKILLS DEVELOPMENT
            PROJECT - NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MANAGEME
topicv3:
Employability, Skills and Jobs m1327054 2131,Secondary Education Graduation m1327059 2152,Education, Skills Development and Labor

abstracts.cdata!:
The Afghanistan Skills and Development
            Project received a moderately satisfactory outcome rating
            with significant risk to development outcome. Both the Bank
            and the Borrower received moderately satisfactory
            performance ratings. A restructuring took place during the
            project that affected the following: A Supplemental Letter
            (Performance Indicators) was included at the time of
            restructuring because of limited progress on developing a
            regulatory and quality assurance framework and some
            indicators and targets were too ambitious or could not be
            measured. Other key changes made include: (i) scope of
            Component 1 was revised to make it achievable; (ii) results
            indicators and targets were revised to make them realistic
            and measurable; (iii) covenants were added to improve the
            implementation of a governance framework; (iv) covenants
            were added to strengthen actions to ensure compliance; (v)
            closing date was extended by 16 months; (vi) a pilot voucher
            program was added; and (vii) training of additional
            vulnerable persons and new training of rehabilitated
            injectable drug users (IDUs) were added under Component 3.
            There were six lessons recorded from this project and they
            are: (1) Strong commitment and leadership are critical for
            successfully steering reforms in a Technical and Vocational
            Education and Training (TVET) institute. (2) Sustained
            implementation support and supervision by the Bank in a
            fragile situation is likely to lead to improved project
            implementation. (3) Even in a challenging fragile situation,
            institutional capacity can be enhanced. (4) Progress on
            improving gender equity is feasible even in situations with
            substantial cultural constraints. (5) Timely project
            restructuring can play a pivotal role in improving project
            implementation. (6) Projects can achieve good results even
            in remote and insecure areas in a fragile context.
